Steve Hunsaker, chair of the Faculty Development Committee

The Faculty Development Committee is pleased to announce the BYU-Idaho Faculty Conference on Learning and Teaching.  The conference will be held Tuesday, September 1, 2009 in the Hinckley Building.  Under the direction of the FDC, the conference has been organized of, by and for faculty members from across campus. Professors from the sciences to the humanities, from the Romney to the Ricks will present on a wide range of topics in a number of interesting and accessible formats.

This kind of in-house conference offers rich and unique opportunities to learn from colleagues and friends.  With the exception of time set aside for the keynote address and the lunch break, there will be six sessions running concurrently throughout the entire day.  The topics of those concurrent sessions are diverse, ranging from the instructional use of technology to educational applications of the principle of faith. 

We will begin our time together with a keynote address from John Ivers, Dean of the College of Language and Letters.  He will speak on ‘Is the American Master Teacher Dead?’

Immediately following Dean Ivers’ address, the concurrent sessions begin.  As noted above, these sessions will be presented in various formats.  In any given hour, attendees will be able to choose from among the many 10-minute, 20-minute, or 60-minute presentations. 

Highlights of the 10-minute presentations include:

  • Mark Nygren, “Born Digital”
  • Doug Ladle, “Service Learning and the Learning Model”
  • Evan Hansen, “Developing A Critical Learning Environment in Physics ”  

From the options in the 20-minute discussion format, conference attendees will be able to choose from presentations like:

  • Brian Pyper, “Physics Education Research in Polynesia”
  • David Ward, “Learning and Teaching through Faith in Christ”


  • John Thomas, “How Does Prior Knowledge Affect Present  Historical Learning?”
  • Nancy Hayes, “Using George Orwell’s “Shooting an Elephant” to demonstrate how we set up others to fail

We will also have panel discussions and workshops that will require a full hour.  Among others, we will hear from:

  • Vaun Waddell, “Students Teaching Students: A Workshop”
  • Scott Samuelson, “Benefits to Students from a Writing and Publishing Faculty: A Panel Discussion ”
For those interested, the department of Instructional Development will also be offering a 3 hour workshop in the Course Design Process concurrent with the conference, allowing faculty to move freely back and forth between the two.


To particiapte, please RSVP to Peggy Clements (496-1140) by August 27th.  We look forward to seeing you.  In the mean time, please feel free to email with any questions.
